poi.title: The Bargate
poi.description: A Grade I listed medieval gatehouse, stands as a prominent icon in Southampton's city centre. Originally constructed around 1180 AD using stone and flint, it served as the primary entrance to the fortified Norman town. Throughout its long history, the Bargate underwent several significant alterations. Around 1290, large drum towers with arrow slits were added to its north side, enhancing its defensive capabilities. The south side received a two-storey extension towards the end of the 13th century.

sections.section: The Bargate is a Grade I listed medieval gatehouse in Southampton's city centre. Originally constructed around 1180 AD using stone and flint, it served as the primary entrance to the fortified Norman town. It underwent several significant alterations over its long history.
Around 1290, large drum towers with arrow slits were added to its north side, enhancing its defensive capabilities. The south side received a two-storey extension towards the end of the 13th century.
The Bargate was eventually separated from the adjoining town walls in the 1930s to accommodate increasing traffic.

poi.title: Arundel Tower
poi.description: A prominent feature of Southampton's medieval town walls, stands at the northwest corner of the old defences. Dating primarily from the late 13th century (around 1260-1300 AD), this impressive half-drum tower was strategically designed for archery defence, featuring two fighting platforms and originally reaching a height of nearly 60 feet, offering commanding views out to sea.

poi.title: Catchcold Tower
poi.description: Sometimes known as Prince Edward's Tower, is a significant circular gun tower forming part of Southampton's western medieval town walls, located just south of Arundel Tower. Constructed in the early 15th century (with first documentary mention in 1429, though some sources suggest by 1420 or 1439), it was a relatively late but crucial addition to the town's defenses, designed specifically to accommodate the larger cannons that were becoming prevalent in warfare.

poi.title: Southampton Castle
poi.description: Southampton Castle's history stretches back to the Norman Conquest in the late 11th century. Strategically positioned in the town's northwest corner overlooking the River Test, it began as a timber motte and bailey design, likely replacing a large English hall.

poi.title: The Arcades
poi.description: Southampton has a fascinating history regarding its arcades, which are more than just shopping thoroughfares; they are an integral part of its medieval defensive walls. The most prominent of these is 'The Arcades' located on the Western Esplanade.

poi.title: Blue Anchor Lane and Tudor House
poi.description: Blue Anchor Lane: This ancient, steeply sloping lane in Southampton's Old Town connects St Michael's Square to the quayside. Originally known as Wytegod's Lane in the 1300s after John Wytegod, a wealthy merchant and mayor who owned property nearby.

poi.title: West Gate
poi.description: The West Gate was a crucial portal in medieval Southampton, providing direct access to West Quay, the town's sole commercial hub at the time. Dating back to the later 14th century, its earliest known name was Florence Stout's Gate.

poi.title: Dancing Man Brewery at the Wool House
poi.description: The Dancing Man Brewery, housed in Southampton's historic Wool House, is a place where centuries of history meet modern craft brewing. The Wool House itself is a remarkable Grade I listed medieval building, dating back to the late 14th century.

poi.title: Gods House Tower
poi.description: A cornerstone of Southampton's Old Town, boasts a rich and varied history stretching back to 1189. Originally known as God's House Gate, its prime function was to guard the Platform Quay, providing seaward access and defense.

poi.title: Holyrood Church
poi.description: Holyrood Church, a significant landmark in Southampton, boasts a history stretching back to Anglo-Saxon times, though the structure visible today was built in 1320. Its name, meaning 'Holy Cross,' hints at an earlier Saxon origin, possibly pre-dating the Norman Conquest.

poi.title: The Red Lion
poi.description: A charming traditional pub with a cozy atmosphere, The Red Lion offers a great selection of ales and hearty meals. Perfect for unwinding after a long day, it features a beer garden and hosts regular live music events.

poi.title: The London Hotel
poi.description: This is Southamptons only LGBTQ+ pub. There are various themed nights throughout the week including drag acts and music bingo, The clientele is stightly older.

poi.title: The Hobbit
poi.description: Emphasizing a cozy, enchanting atmosphere inspired by Tolkien's world, The Hobbit is a quirky pub that is just different enough to avoid copyright claims. There is often live music, heavy metal, rock and emo. They have dozens of different pint cocktails to drink in the large garden in the back. Remember your ID as everyone is checked and scanned.

poi.title: The Social
poi.description: A trendy spot for both food and drinks, The Social is known for its creative cocktails and modern food offerings. Its vibrant interior draws in a youthful crowd, making it a lively place to socialize.

poi.title: The Dolphin
poi.description: Located near the waterfront, The Dolphin is known for its relaxed ambiance and great sea views. It offers fresh seafood options along with an extensive drinks list, making it a popular dining destination.

poi.title: The Edge
poi.description: Lively LGBTQ+ club with a dance floor, a stage and a patio, plus a music-free zone and a cocktail bar.

poi.title: The Standing Order
poi.description: An old bank now repurposed as a Wetherspoon. If you didn't know Wetherspoons are a national chain known for their Cheap drinks and OK food. The menu includes most traditional pub meals.

poi.title: Duke of Wellington
poi.description: Historic building dating back to 1220 serves real ales and traditional food, plus open mic nights.

poi.title: Dark Arts Potion Bar
poi.description: Serving fancy cocktails with a fastasy/Wizzarding theme

poi.title: Board in the City
poi.description: This board game cafe has hundreds of games to play. The friendly staff will help by explaining the rules if you want to try something new. They have all the usual cafe fare and some basic food. This venue is run as a charitable business and booking is advised.

poi.title: Royal Pier Indian restaurant
poi.description: This eatery has recently changed hands and has mixed review. I can't comment on the food, but the building has some beautiful architecture

poi.title: Town Quay
poi.description: This quay is where you enbarqe for passenger services to the Isle of Wight. The trip is recommended. There is a slow car ferry and a fast passenger ferry. Said by some to be the worlds most expensive ferry for the distance

poi.title: Ottoman Kitchen
poi.description: Award winning Turkish restaurant

poi.title: Edisons
poi.description: Is it a cafe or an estate agent, we are not sure, what do you think?

poi.title: Coriander Lounge
poi.description: Highly rated Indian Restaurant

poi.title: Lidl
poi.description: City centre discount supermarket

poi.title: Rocket Ronnies
poi.description: Pool hall with table tennis

poi.title: Decathlon
poi.description: If you are off camping and forgotten something try here. They have equipment for most sports at a good price

poi.title: West Quay
poi.description: This is Southamptons main shopping centre (mall). There are many entrances, the marker is at the above bar entrance. There are a great variety of shops with a food court at the top floor. The two largest shops are Marks and Spencer and John Lewis

poi.title: The Quays
poi.description: Sports centre with leasure pool and a flume

poi.title: The Platform Tavern
poi.description: Old school boozer in Southampton's dockyard serving pub lunches, sandwiches and all day breakfasts.

poi.title: High Score Arcade
poi.description: A huge variety of free to play arcade machines, you pay by the hour

poi.title: Maritimo Lounge
poi.description: Modern cain pub with food and drink

poi.title: Harbour Lights Picture House
poi.description: Cinema

poi.title: Solent Sky
poi.description: Museum of flight

poi.title: Showcase Cinema
poi.description: Cinema

poi.title: Central Station
poi.description: Direct Trains to London, the north and the west

poi.title: Seacity Museum
poi.description: Facinating look at the history of the city focusing on the Titanic crew, 699 of which were from Southampton. The city was the Titanics origin point

poi.title: City Art Gallery
poi.description: The city has a collection of art, and he gallery has temporary exhibits. Free

poi.title: Mayflower Theatre
poi.description: Often famous plays and musicals make their way here

poi.title: Cafe Thrive
poi.description: Good selection of vegan food

poi.title: John Hansard Gallery
poi.description: Rotating art exhibits, Free

poi.title: Mettricks
poi.description: A local chain of cafes, drinks are good, service is outstanding.

poi.title: National Express Coach Station
poi.description: National coach service. Particularly good for services to Heathrow

poi.title: ASDA
poi.description: Large supermarket in the city centre

poi.title: Turtle Bay
poi.description: Caribean style food with great cocktails

poi.title: Medieval Merchants House
poi.description: Ancient Building

poi.title: Digital Darts at O'Neils
poi.description: Darts with digital games and scoring in a pub
